Issues.Title: refactor(core): remove unused or testing-only utilities from DomAdapters
Issues.Body:
`DomAdapter` is brought into every Angular application by default, but it's pretty large in size. This PR attempts to clean out the parts of `DomAdapter` that are:

- completely unused at the moment
- used only by tests run in a browser environment (in which case the utils are moved to platform-browser)
- jasmine matchers used only by tests run in a browser environment

For these cases, there's no point including the code into production bundles. The moved code will be tree-shaken away. This seems to save about 3-4KB.

None of the parts of `DomAdapter` that are actually used at runtime should be affected.

Note: This PR only tackles half of `DomAdapter` because the PR started to get big. There will be follow-up PRs.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(core): remove unused or testing-only utilities from DomAdapters" (#32278)

Issues.Title: build: patch terser to create proper source-maps [do not merge]
Issues.Body:
Currently terser is in a broken state where technically unmapped
bytes in the input file are mapped back to random source files.

To clarify the term "unmapped bytes": In the input file there are bytes
which cannot be mapped back to any source file. This can happen if code
will be generated by tools automatically. e.g. TSC generating decorator helpers, or
rollup creating bundles of multiple files (there will be boilerplate to merge multiple
files into a bundle). These bytes do not originate from any source-file and therefore
are "unmapped". Read more about 1-variable length segments in the [source-map spec](https://sourcemaps.info/spec.html)

In the current state of Terser where unmapped bytes are mapped to
random source-files, size tracking tools are not able to determine
accurate payload size contribution numbers of individual source-files,
nor do the broken source-maps help with debugging Angular packages
as some bytes are incorrectly mapping to a wrong file (this is not a
big deal though as the generated code is not likely to be debugged).

For context why we try to fix the terser bug on our side now: A PR
to fix this bug on the terser side has been submitted but it had to
be reverted due to a bug in the latest `mozilla/source-map` library.
Terser reverted the fix that hit the bug in `mozilla/source-map` as
they wanted to unblock consumers that use the latest `source-map`
package. Problem is that the bug in the `source-map` package is widely
spread and there doesn't seem to be a fix for it any time soon. Meaning
that source-maps need to stay broken/incorrect as fixing them would
always cause developers to hit the `source-map` bug...

This PR should just be an example of how correct source-maps
should look like (helpful when comparing size differences)

See `source-map` bug: https://github.com/mozilla/source-map/issues/385
See Terser fix: https://github.com/terser-js/terser/pull/342.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: patch terser to create proper source-maps [do not merge]" (#32277)

Issues.Title: feat(service-worker): add support for specifying `cache.match()` options for asset-/data-groups
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/service-worker ### Is this a regression? Yes, I assumed this worked for previous versions but this is the first time trying to implement it. ### Description I have implemented a pretty standard service worker with the below configuration: ``` { "index": "/index.html", "assetGroups": [ { "name": "app", "installMode": "prefetch", "resources": { "files": [ "/favicon.ico", "/index.html", "/*.css", "/*.js" ] } }, { "name": "assets", "installMode": "lazy", "updateMode": "prefetch", "resources": { "files": [ "/assets/**", "/legacy/**", "/*.(eot|svg|cur|jpg|png|webp|gif|otf|ttf|woff|woff2|ani)" ] } } ], "navigationUrls": [ "/**", "!/**/*.*", "!/**/*__*", "!/**/*__*/**", "!/**/faqs", "!/**/terms-and-conditions", ] } ``` The service worker is working properly as far as putting what I want into cache and busting it when a new version is found. The problem is that all requests that match what is in the cache end up going to the network no matter what. After spending a lot of time debugging the ngsw-worker.js that angular generates, I found that all requests that where being checked by `cache.match` where not found. The reason for that is the headers of the requests coming from my app were a little different than the request headers stored in cache. Specifically the `referrer-policy` header is different. The incoming request has the header set to `Referrer Policy: no-referrer-when-downgrade` but the header for the matching request in cache is `Referrer Policy: unsafe-url`. One way I proved that this was the issue was by using the `cache.match()` options flag `ignoreVary: true` to ignore header differences. After making that change my app's service worker pulled all in scope assets from cache and didn't go to the network. Because the `ngsw-worker.js` is generated I don't think modifying it is a valid option. I dug deeper to see why the request headers where being mismatched. What I found was that the request that is being put in to cache `cache.put(req, res)` is accurate, but when you immediately pull that same request from cache the headers are changed. There is something that happens when executing `cache.put()` that modifies the request headers and I am not sure what. Is there anything from an angular service worker configuration that would cause this? Would it be possible to update the generated service worker to use the `ignoreVary` option when checking for matches in cache? ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/... To reproduce this just execute the two statements below in a browser console and compare the request objects. caches.open('exampleTest1').then(cache => {var newreq = new Request("https://www.google.com"); console.log('NEW REQUEST: ', newreq); cache.put(newreq, new Response('hello'))}) caches.open('exampleTest1').then(res => res.keys().then(keys => console.log(keys))) ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Issues.Title: Dynamic import of script not available globally
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Description I'm migrating an Angular application using a custom Webpack configuration to an Angular CLI application. In one particular component, the component is using require.ensure(...) to import JS scripts needed for the component. Example: ``` require.ensure([], require => { const TweenLite = require('../../../../../assets/external-js/TweenLite.min'); let confettiCannon = require('../../../../../assets/external-js/confetti'); this.confettiCannon = confettiCannon = new confettiCannon.ConfettiCannon(); confettiCannon.start(); }); ``` TweenLite.min.js is a GSAP plugin used for simple transitions. confetti.js is a custom script that loads a canvas animation. When confettiCannon.start() is run eventually it will try to use the TweenLite plugin - which is resulting in an error because TweenLite is `undefined`. With my previous Angular application this code works fine, and since when running the confetti.js TweenLite is listed as undefined my hunch was that the plugin is not being attached to the window. Below is a sample of the differences between the code that is returned by Webpack from my two applications: _Working Application (custom webpack config)_ ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36479149/63606218-d2f9d000-c5cf-11e9-954f-f68349402feb.png) _Failing Application (using Angular CLI)_ ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36479149/63606251-ead15400-c5cf-11e9-8716-5cf39cd59cb9.png) The difference between the two scripts is that the working sample wraps the imported script with a `function(global) { ... }`. I'm guessing that with this Webpack is able to attach the script globally. So my question is, is it possible to dynamically import a JS file and somehow make it available globally? I don't know if there's any CLI configuration or Webpack loader that could help with this scenario. ## üåç Your Environment 


Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.802.2
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.802.2
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.802.2
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.802.2

Issues.Title: ng generate library adds tsickle 0.36.0 dependency, incompatible to typescript 3.5
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Description

@angular/cli@8.3.0

ng new creates a project for an app, with a dependency to typescript 3.5
ng generate library adds a dependency to tsickle 0.36.0, which is incompatible to typescript 3.5.

as a consequence library providers cannot use typescript 3.5.
Removing the dependency to tsickle will brake ng build my-lib

So either tsickle should be made compatible to typescript 3.5, or the dependency to tsickle should be removed.

also see https://github.com/angular/tsickle/issues/1048


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

```shell
ng new lib-test
cd lib-test
ng generate library my-lib
```


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/545229/63589454-81d6e580-c5a9-11e9-8fb4-8e21b617022a.png)



## üî• Exception or Error

If i remove tsickle manually, ng build will not run anymore:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/545229/63589673-0cb7e000-c5aa-11e9-9ba7-0f01ed497f27.png)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): default poll value when not present
Issues.Body: `--poll` is a valid command line option (vs. `--poll 1000`).  This however will result in a value of 0 which causes polling to be disabled rather than enabled which is completely non-obvious.  This change sets a default value of 500 when the commandline flag is used.

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): implements items type for guard schematic
Issues.Body:
Fixes the type of the items in the `schema.json` for `implements`, as `enum` is not picked up by the CLI.
Also migrates the existing e2e test to `async/await` and adds another one with `implements` to avoid regressions.

My previous PR #15313 fixed an issue in the guard schematic but introduced a regression (sorry!) as:

```json
"items": {
  "enum": [
    "CanActivate",
    "CanActivateChild",
    "CanLoad"
  ]
},
```
is not picked up by the CLI, so `--implements` ends up not being recognized when running:

    ng g guard foo --implements=CanActivate

The regression was released in CLI v8.3.0 stable (not in the next or rc releases).

If the issue is encountered, it can be easily worked around by using `--defaults` or manually picking the interface wanted in the prompt.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@schematics/angular): implements items type for guard schematic" (#15412)

Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)

### Is this a regression?

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Yes, the previous version  in which this bug was not present was: (7.x)


### Description

Terser minifies js files in assets. I think it should not transform assets files in any way.

  "optimization": false,
  "buildOptimizer": false,

ng new ang8

and by minifing it Terser breaks it unfortunately:(

Issues.Title: [ng add]: support for dev dependencies
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [X] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
For our library, we want to provide schematics for the `ng add` command. However, this automatically installs our library as `dependency`. Shouldn't there be a way to install it to the `devDependencies`?

We do add our library to the `devDependencies` our selves (using schematics), but that results in the following warning:

```
Installed packages for tooling via npm.
    ‚úÖÔ∏è Added "foo" into devDependencies
    üîç Installing packages...
UPDATE package.json (980 bytes)
npm WARN The package foo is included as both a dev and production dependency.
```


### Describe the solution you'd like
* Support for an additional `dev` option: `ng add mylib --dev`.
* Update the `npmInstall()` task with an additional `dev: boolean` argument.

This could be done in a backwards compatible way.

### Alternative solution

* Let `ng add` perform an `npm install --no-save`
* Change the `package.json` ourselves

This might be breaking.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[ng add]: support for dev dependencies" (#15409)

Issues.Title: Use custom error reporter
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
In our company we build the angular applications with Teamcity. Teamcity has a special [format ](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/teamcity/build-script-interaction-with-teamcity.html#BuildScriptInteractionwithTeamCity-ServiceMessages) for build/compile logging. Because angular-cli always logs errors in it's "console format" the errors are not reported nicely in teamcity.


### Describe the solution you'd like
Provide an API where custom error loggers / reporters can be hooked in. I'm thinking about an approach similar to the approach Karma uses, where you can use e.g. the [teamcity reporter](https://github.com/karma-runner/karma-teamcity-reporter).

Problem is that I don't know if this is possible, because I don't know if webpack offers the possibility to do something like this. 

### Other solution
Optionally provide build output in some machine readable format like JSON or XML.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Use custom error reporter" (#15408)

Issues.Title: AngularElement in a CDK Overlay
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

It's difficult to create a repro, since I'd need to host the Angular Element.  I'll try to setup a repo.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create an Angular Element that leverages a CdkOverlay Material widget (tooltip, select, etc)
2. Place that selector in a CdkOverlay (MatDialog, for example).

As soon you interact with the "inner" CdkOverlay by hovering over the tooltip or activating the select, the host CdkOverlay will just crash without an error message I can pick up on.

This might not really be a bug, but rather a limitation of Angular Elements, but being that it can be triggered in our environment with simple widgets I wonder if there's not some way I can get the Angular Elements to play well with the host.

The Angular Elements work fine when not hosted in a CdkOverlay.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
CdkOverlay within Angular Element plays well with the host.

#### Actual Behavior

Acitvation of the CdkOverlay within an Angular Element causes the host CdkOverlay to silently crash.

Issues.Title: Removing "previous" Overlay containers breaks other OverlayContainer instances
Issues.Body:
A fix from Jul 18, 2019 removes all "previous" overlay container elements of the DOM:
https://github.com/angular/components/commit/036729dc1a7b41236fcda9b23c578f9ef65b484c#diff-80f4f593448bba8d614136a94c0c9c5c
@crisbeto @jelbourn 

The problem here is, that there might be other OverlayContainer instances active in the application (as an example: Child components might create a new FullScreenOverlayContainer instances, if their injector does not contain an active instance yet) , and by selecting all DOM elements by a class selector, you are detaching these overlay container elements from the DOM as well. 
```
// Remove any old containers. This can happen when transitioning from the server to the client.
    for (let i = 0; i < previousContainers.length; i++) {
      previousContainers[i].parentNode!.removeChild(previousContainers[i]);
    }
```
I hope I find the time to reproduce this issue in stackblitz in the near future, but the issue is quite easy to mentally comprehend: 

Imagine two compoennts compA and compB, and each of them have separate OverlayContainer instances injected to them.

Now CompA attaches a portal to its OverlayContainer. No container element has been created for his OverlayContainer instance yet, so the _createContainer() method is being called. All "previous" containers are being cleared (which isn't a problem yet) and a new one is created. The overlay is being displayed correctly.

Now CompB attaches a portal to its component overlay. No Container Element has been created for his OverlayContainer instance yet, so the _createContainer() method is being called. All "previous" containers are being cleared, **including the container element of the OverlayContainer of compA**. The overlay of comB is being display correctly.

Now CompA tries to attach another portal to its OverlayContainer. His OverlayContainer still references the container element it has created before.

`
if (!this._containerElement) {
      this._createContainer();
 }
`

**So, NO new container element is being created.. However, this container element has been detached from the DOM earlier by the OverlayContainer from compB. So now we can attach whatever we want to this container, they won't be displayed in the DOM.** 

To fix this issue, three solutions should be examined:

1. If it's true that there always should only be ONE container element, independent of the OverlayContainer instance, then the getContainerElement() method should not check, whether or not a reference exists in the particular instance, but instead perform a dom query, as it's done currently done, when existing container elements are removed
2. If it's true that there should only be ONE container element per OverlayContainer instance, than these containers should have some sort of ID attached to them, so we only remove the containers refering to this instance
3. The proposed fix targets a situation caused by server-side-rendering using angular universal. Maybe there is a different solution to address this issue.


#### Reproduction
I hope I can build a stackblitz for this issue soon. However, I think I've explained the problem  
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2
- CDK/Material: 8.1
- Browser(s):
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Removing "previous" Overlay containers breaks other OverlayContainer instances" (#16851)

Issues.Title: FEATURE REQUEST: Move Material Components' styleUrls to a global stylesheet similar to traditional CSS.
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
I would like to propose the moving of all styles declared in Angular Material's Components' styleUrl property to be moved to a global stylesheet that users import manually through many means such as ```style``` tag, ```@import``` etc...

#### What is the expected behavior?
The expected behavior is that I do NOT want angular material to load any default styles through the ```styleUrls``` property of the component and rather load it via a global stylesheet. 

That way if I am prepared to take responsibility on the consequences of not loading any of those default styles I can do it without having to resort to class overriding or other techniques.

#### What is the current behavior?

Just so you have a perspective, my colleagues are consuming components such as Angular Material's ```MatFormField``` with ```matInput``` directives mainly for the purposes of using the functionality to do things such as showing validation errors, showing hint text of the number of characters remaining inside of a text field etc. However, ```MatFormField``` component injects the following CSS in its style urls:

Below fragment taken from https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/form-field/form-field.ts

```
styleUrls: [
    'form-field.css',
    'form-field-fill.css',
    'form-field-input.css',
    'form-field-legacy.css',
    'form-field-outline.css',
    'form-field-standard.css',
  ]
```

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Simply look at this file and the class ```MatFormField``` in https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/form-field/form-field.ts

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?
My colleagues wish to use Angular Material mainly for the reason it takes care of most of the javascript functionality required without having to write their own code to do the same thing. 

However, we have our own CSS framework which has stylings exactly to our organisation's needs and I feel that the need to import Angular Material's CSS that are embedded through a component's ```styleUrls``` property simply adds bloat and maintenance burden we simply don't need.

Just so you have a perspective, my colleagues are consuming components such as Angular Material's ```MatFormField``` with ```matInput``` directives mainly for the purposes of using the functionality to do things such as showing validation errors, showing hint text of the number of characters remaining inside of a text field etc. However, ```MatFormField``` component injects the following CSS in its style urls:

Below fragment taken from https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/form-field/form-field.ts

```
styleUrls: [
    'form-field.css',
    'form-field-fill.css',
    'form-field-input.css',
    'form-field-legacy.css',
    'form-field-outline.css',
    'form-field-standard.css',
  ]
```
The big kick in the gut is that because we have our own CSS that can take care of the look and feel of the some of these components but we are forced to firstly cancel out all of the CSS that is used in Angular material first before we can proceed to style our own thing. Furthermore, since we are not intending to use what is provided by Angular Material out of the box in terms of CSS styling, it's better that we might as well not include it all.

Furthermore, in terms of the form field component, you guys are not using any form of ```ViewEncapsulation``` at all, so apart from loading order of the CSS files, it doesn't make much of a difference to a global stylesheet, so I feel this request is not unreasonable.

I feel the people in my team are experienced enough in CSS that I feel we can take responsibility for our own actions of what happens there.

So basically we want to use your JS functionality but give us the option not to use your CSS and allow us the freedom and responsibility to maintain the look and feel ourselves. :)

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
I'm going to make the assumption of all versions of Angular Material that can be consumed in Angular 2 onwards since this is a conscious code structure decision made by the Angular Material team. All browsers.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "FEATURE REQUEST: Move Material Components' styleUrls to a global stylesheet similar to traditional CSS." (#16849)

the ngModel behavior: 

radio:

Issues.Title: Chips: Choice chips
Issues.Body:
build-in Choice chips as material guidelines.

Choice chips
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8691013/63512022-53a7c600-c515-11e9-8514-8b205690d940.png)

choice chips need 2 feature, 
1. select by click not keyboard space.
2. when user select, it can't be unselect anymore (like radio, toggle button)

for workaround i can do like this.
```
<mat-chip-list [formControl]="formControl" aria-label="Fish selection">
  <mat-chip #chip1="matChip" [selectable]="!chip1.selected" (click)="chip1.selectable && chip1.toggleSelected(true)" >One fish</mat-chip>
  <mat-chip #chip2="matChip" [selectable]="!chip2.selected" (click)="chip2.selectable && chip2.toggleSelected(true)" >Two fish</mat-chip>
  <mat-chip #chip3="matChip" [selectable]="!chip3.selected" (click)="chip3.selectable && chip3.toggleSelected(true)" >Primary fish</mat-chip>
  <mat-chip #chip4="matChip" [selectable]="!chip4.selected" (click)="chip4.selectable && chip4.toggleSelected(true)" >Accent fish</mat-chip>
</mat-chip-list>
```

Issues.Title: fix FocusMonitor issue in IE by switching to focusin and focusout events
Issues.Body:
Fixes #15517.

Not ready to merge just yet, but I wanted to get this up and get any feedback in case I haven't fully understood the potential impact.

- [ ] Fully update documentation
- [ ] Add more coverage to `focus-monitor.spec.ts` for this use case
- [ ] Rebase and squash

TLDR of the issue:

> When you monitor a parent element with `checkChildren` set to `true`, internally the focus monitor listens for both `focus` and `blur` events on the parent element. When focus shifts from child element 1 to child element 2, the `blur` event on child element 1 is captured first. The design is that this `blur` event does not result in a `null` value on the subject, because the focus monitor will see that the [event's `relatedTarget`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FocusEvent/relatedTarget) (the element that's about to take the focus) is also a child of our parent element, [and take no further action](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/2d976a92429ed37a89bfa9ee74b479b48c7ac40d/src/cdk/a11y/focus-monitor/focus-monitor.ts#L375).
> 
> However, IE does not set the `relatedTarget` on `focus` or `blur` events, so the focus monitor can't know that focus is not leaving the parent element, and so we get a `null` value on the subject.

The solution here is to listen for the `focusin` and `focusout` events instead, where IE _does_ set the `relatedTarget` correctly (along with all other browsers). Other than this, there are some differences between the two sets of events:

- `focusin` and `focusout` support bubbling, where `focus` and `blur` do not - I don't think this makes any difference for our use case, as we are explicitly using capture mode anyway
- `focusin` and `focusout` fire _after_ their counterparts `focus` and `blur` - it's theoretically possible the some users may be relying on an order of events, but given there's no documentation that spells out when the focus monitor emits in relation to, say, model changes, I don't think it should be considered a breaking change

(I've not been able to run the full test suite on Windows due to #16632, and linting on Windows is a non-starter because of line breaks, so I'll be testing properly on my Mac later)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix FocusMonitor issue in IE by switching to focusin and focusout events" (#16840)
